items.title: Dry January is back. And no, it doesn't annoy these NYC bar owners.
items.description: Now, more than ever, they have stuff to sell you.

image.title: Courtesy Abby Ehmann - grand opening toast.jpg
image.caption: An alcohol-free toast at the grand opening of Hekate Café & Elixir Lounge.

items.title: Law meant to make bail more affordable in New York isn’t working, report finds
items.description: Researchers studied a little-known portion of the controversial law in the first four years it was in effect.

image.title: GettyImages-1195677473.jpg
image.alt: A sign advertises services for bail bonds along Atlantic Avenue near the Brooklyn Detention Complex in Brooklyn, New York, December 21, 2019. A state license is required to be a bail bondsman.
image.caption: A sign advertises services for bail bonds along Atlantic Avenue near the Brooklyn Detention Complex in Brooklyn, New York, December 21, 2019. A state license is required to be a bail bondsman.

related_authors.biography: Samantha reports on whether New Yorkers feel safe and whether the institutions that are supposed to protect them are working. Before coming to WNYC/Gothamist, she spent three years covering the criminal justice system in Tennessee for Nashville Public Radio. Her reporting on Nashville's police department received multiple awards, including the Daniel Schorr Journalism Prize. Samantha was also part of the inaugural class of Report for America, a service journalism program that sends up-and-coming reporters to local newsrooms across the country. She is a Northwestern University grad, a Baltimore native and fluent in Spanish. Got a tip? Email smax@nypublicradio.org or Signal: samanthamaxwnyc.93.

items.title: Early Addition: Limos were cool
items.description: Because a Yukon XL doesn't have the same spice, here are your early links: George Santos wants to stay out of prison a little longer to keep podcasting, Hipster Grifter wrote a book, “Shrek” donkey died and more.

image.title: limo.jpg
image.alt: two women outside a limo on 5th Avenue

items.title: NYC Board of Elections head keeps job after watchdog found he made racial, sexual jokes
items.description: Executive Director Mike Ryan was suspended for three weeks without pay after the city's Department of Investigation substantiated allegations of harassment against him.

image.title: ryan.PNG
image.alt: A man in front of a Board of Elections seal.
image.caption: Board of Elections executive director Mike Ryan.

related_authors.biography: Brigid Bergin is an award-winning senior reporter on the People and Power desk. She is fiercely committed to telling stories that help people engage and support democracy. In 2022, she hosted a live, ten-week call-in politics show ahead of the midterm elections called The People's Guide to Power. Brigid's reporting in 2017 included some of the first coverage of a political newcomer now known as AOC. In 2016, she broke the news of a voter purge in Brooklyn just days before New York’s presidential primary, triggering city, state and federal investigations. Brigid also guest hosts The Brian Lehrer Show and All Of It. She graduated from the University at Albany and the CUNY Newmark School of Journalism. Got a tip? Email bbergin@wnyc.org or Signal 917-723-4719.

items.title: Woman stabbed to death at Staten Island public housing development, NYPD says
items.description: Police said they were still looking for suspects in one of the borough’s first killings of the year.

image.title: 00187.JPG
image.alt: Police officers stand at a corner in Staten Island near the Richmond County Clerk on March 8, 2024.
image.caption: Police officers stand at a corner in Staten Island near the Richmond County Clerk on March 8, 2024.

related_authors.biography: Brittany Kriegstein covers all breaking news around New York City, with a focus on crime and gun violence. Got a tip? Email Brittany at bkriegstein@nypublicradio.org.

items.title: Popular home care program undergoing overhaul begins outreach to 250K New Yorkers
items.description: Hundreds of intermediary or “go-between” companies are being replaced with a single firm.

image.title: GettyImages-2012840901.jpg
image.alt: Image of health care consumer receiving services in their home

related_authors.biography: Caroline Lewis is on the health care beat for WNYC and Gothamist. She has covered COVID, a nurses' strike, the overdose crisis and New York’s marijuana legalization effort, and spent a year investigating patients' medical bills. She always wants to hear about how everyday New Yorkers experience the health system. Got a tip? Email clewis@wnyc.org.

items.title: Gov. Hochul looks to expand forced hospitalization as Albany returns to session
items.description: The Democratic governor is putting her muscle behind efforts to ease restrictions in New York’s involuntary commitment law, which have stalled in recent years.

image.title: 54213636075_a765c010a1_k.jpg
image.alt: Gov. Kathy Hochul speaks at a podium
image.caption: Hochul has made crime in the subways a priority as the new legislative session begins.

related_authors.biography: Jon Campbell covers the New York State Capitol for WNYC and Gothamist. Prior to that, he covered the Capitol for more than a decade for the USA TODAY Network. He has twice earned the Walter T. Brown Memorial Award, an honor given annually by the Legislative Correspondents Association alumni for outstanding state government coverage. Jon grew up in the Buffalo area and graduated from the University at Albany. Got a tip? Email Jon at jcampbell@wnyc.org or Signal 518-210-7087.

items.title: Manhattan Community Board 4 votes to oppose casino complex proposed for Hudson Yards
items.description: The advisory board's vote against the sprawling development by Wynn New York City was unanimous.

image.title: Hudson Green_Summer_Rendering Courtesy of Related Companies and Wynn Resorts.jpg
image.alt: Rendering of the proposed Wynn New York City casino and resort development at Hudson Yards in Manhattan.
image.caption: Rendering of the proposed Wynn New York City casino and resort development at Hudson Yards in Manhattan.
image.credit: Courtesy of Wynn New York City

related_authors.biography:
Arun Venugopal is a senior reporter for the WNYC and Gothamist Race & Justice Unit who focuses on issues of race and bias in our region. His reporting also tackles the topics of immigration, faith, and inequality. Arun serves as the regular fill-in host of the station's "U.S. of Anxiety" program.

Arun was the creator and host of Micropolis, a series about race and identity. He is a contributor to NPR's Morning Edition and All Things Considered. He has appeared on PBS Newshour, On the Media and Studio 360, and has been published in The Guardian, The Wall Street Journal and Salon. He also frequently serves as an emcee and moderator of panel discussions on race, religion, and identity issues and has been a guest host of NPR's "Fresh Air." He lives with his family in Queens.

items.title: $163K jewelry heist: NYC thieves use distractions to pull off multi-borough thefts, police say
items.description: Police are seeking the public’s help identifying the suspects in a series of brazen grand larcenies targeting packages and vehicles.

image.title: 00015.JPG
image.alt: A police barricade sits outside the NYPD's 73rd Precinct in Brooklyn on March 4, 2024.
image.caption: A police barricade sits outside the NYPD's 73rd Precinct in Brooklyn on March 4, 2024.

related_authors.biography: Phil Corso is the evening news editor at WNYC/Gothamist. Got a tip? Email pcorso@nypublicradio.org.

items.title: 2 bodies found in JetBlue plane’s landing gear after flight from JFK
items.description: The bodies were discovered during a post-flight inspection in Florida.

image.caption: A general view of a jetBlue airliner headed towards JFK Airport on Aug. 23, 2024.

related_authors.biography:
Giulia Heyward is a breaking news reporter on the Day-Of desk. She previously worked at NPR, as a breaking news reporter, and the New York Times, as a reporting fellow on the national desk. Her work has also appeared in CNN, The Atlantic and Politico. 

Got a tip? Email gheyward@nypublicradio.org or more securely on signal at 917-715-1458.
